name: Pediatrics

points: Lowest compensation in medicine despite same training as other specialties
Medicaid payer mix (40%+ of patients) with reimbursement well below Medicare rates
87% feel unfairly compensated relative to work complexity
Student loan burden ($200-300k) with limited earning potential
Real income decreased 6.7% since 2017 after adjusting for inflation
Gender pay gap - women earn 93% of male counterparts despite being 63% of workforce
42-55% burnout rate (4th highest among all specialties)
Dual patient relationships - managing both child and anxious parents
Compassion fatigue from caring for sick children and stressed families
48% report not feeling valued by their organization
Rising childhood mental health crisis without adequate resources
Medical mistrust and vaccine hesitancy creating difficult parent conversations
Excessive bureaucratic tasks and EHR documentation
Working from home to complete charting and admin work regularly
Work interfering with personal/family responsibilities
Gender disparities - women handle more household duties while working
Only 43% report appropriate work-life balance
Average 43 hours per week with 36 hours in direct patient care
Severe workforce shortage - 30% of residency positions unfilled in 2024
Fewer medical students choosing pediatrics than in 30 years
High patient volumes needed to maintain productivity targets
Insufficient time per patient for quality care
Inadequate staffing and support resources
Concerns about Medicaid cuts affecting patient access to care

motivations: Better work-life balance and predictable schedule
Higher compensation to address student loans and financial security
Part-time opportunities (25-33% of pediatricians work part-time)
Better payer mix with less Medicaid dependence
More time per patient for quality care
Reduced work hours or flexible scheduling
Location change for family or lifestyle reasons
Better organizational support and feeling valued

opening: Tell me about your current practice setting and patient population
What's driving you to explore new opportunities at this stage of your career?
Help me understand what you're hoping to find in your next position
Walk me through a typical day - clinic hours, patient volume, administrative time
painDiscovery: You mentioned [challenge] - help me understand how that's affecting you daily
Tell me more about what led you to start looking for something different
Describe your current work-life balance and where the biggest frustrations are
How has your current compensation affected your ability to meet financial goals?
Share with me your experience managing both the children and their parents
Help me understand your administrative burden - hours in EHR, after-hours work
clinical: Describe your patient population - age range, acuity, typical conditions
Help me understand your current patient volume - how many do you see daily?
Tell me about your payer mix - percentage Medicaid, commercial insurance, self-pay
Walk me through your practice setting - outpatient only, hospital privileges, combination?
Share your experience with newborn care, well-child visits, acute illness management
What's your comfort level with behavioral health issues and managing complex cases?
Tell me about your after-hours coverage and call requirements
motivation: When you think about your ideal practice, what does it look like?
What would need to be true about a position for you to feel excited about it?
Help me understand your priorities in making this career move
Tell me about your long-term career goals - where do you see yourself in 5 years?
What aspects of pediatrics do you find most rewarding?
compensation: Help me understand your current compensation structure - base, bonuses, benefits
When you think about your next position, what compensation package would make a move worthwhile?
Tell me about your financial goals and what's driving those expectations
How important is work-life balance versus compensation in your decision-making?
Share your thoughts on part-time versus full-time work

commonChallenges.challenge: Compensation too low compared to debt
commonChallenges.response: Help me understand your financial priorities and what complete compensation package would address your needs - base, loan repayment, benefits, retirement?

commonChallenges.challenge: Too much Medicaid - want better payer mix
commonChallenges.response: What payer mix would feel sustainable for you? Help me understand what percentage Medicaid would work with the right support and compensation structure

commonChallenges.challenge: Work-life balance impossible with current demands
commonChallenges.response: Describe your ideal work schedule - days per week, hours per day, patient volume, after-hours expectations

commonChallenges.challenge: Want part-time but concerned about compensation
commonChallenges.response: Walk me through what part-time means to you - hours, days, patient volume - and what compensation would make that work financially

commonChallenges.challenge: Dealing with vaccine hesitancy is exhausting
commonChallenges.response: Tell me about the organizational support and resources that would help you navigate these difficult conversations more effectively
What level of administrative support - scribes, MA support, protected time - would make the EHR and paperwork manageable?

commonChallenges.challenge: Want to subspecialize to escape general peds challenges
commonChallenges.response: Help me understand what specifically about general pediatrics isn't working and what subspecialty focus interests you

challengingOpportunities: You mentioned wanting [specific location/setting]. Help me understand what NEED that solves - there might be other ways to meet that same need with better compensation or work-life balance
I hear you prefer avoiding [Medicaid-heavy or high-volume setting]. If I could address your underlying concern about compensation and support in a different way, would you be open to exploring it?
Many pediatricians find that what they thought they wanted differs from what actually makes them happy. What's truly non-negotiable - compensation, schedule, payer mix, or something else?
You mentioned compensation is the priority. If I could show you a position addressing work-life balance so dramatically you'd avoid burnout, how would that factor into your decision?
